Ooh no, not that! *runs to a nuclear shelter*


--- In nbwrpg@y..., KSLawdogg@c... wrote:
> (Unfortunately this post was made a day late, nonetheless, it will 
be in 
> honor of the holiest day known to the cosmos.  My birthday, the 
twenty-eigth 
> of January.  Let the resurrection of the Chaos-Bringer and the 
teachings of 
> Doherty be brought about.  Of course, Yan's the only one who will 
know what I 
> mean about the latter.)
> 
> 
> Vehement/Sun Crusher/Reflector:
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> The Archbishop and his fellow Brotherhood members were passed by 
Chile, South 
> America by quite a bit, and their destination was now clear.  Rapa 
Nui.
> 
> The Archbishop smiled with an evil grin, thinking of something 
philosophical. 
>  "As we come closer to the island, we come closer to our destiny, 
my 
> brothers.  As we come closer to that piece of dirt, we come closer 
to our 
> destiny and our god."
> 
> ---
> 
> Vehement landed several miles from a high volcano.  "Rana Kao.  So 
beautiful, 
> especially when we know it is mixed with the Brotherhood and Divine 
One's 
> destiny so much." The Brotherhood leader lept into the air, his 
feet boosters 
> activating him once more, only the robot didn't go high into the 
air.
> 
> He stayed only five feet off the ground, heading for the volcano at 
full 
> speed, his two minions following close behind, all three with high 
spirits.
> 
> After several minutes of high speed flying, Vehement pulled out the 
Key, 
> letting the black orb shine in the sunlight that beamed down on the 
tropical 
> Rapa Nui, the South American island shaped like a triangle with 
three 
> volcanoes on each tip.  And the Brotherhood was at one of the 
volcanoes at 
> the southwestern tip for a reason unknown to them, only that it 
will further 
> their cause.  But it ways more than they know of.
> 
> The three Brotherhood members could easily see that as sunlight 
reflected 
> upon the black sphere that was called the Key, the sphere itself 
reflected an 
> emerald glow onto the volcano.
> 
> Vehement walked towards the inactive Rana Kao, still holding the 
Key in the 
> almost exact same position, seeing where the emerald glow was at 
precisely.  
> A small hole was in the rocky mountain, about the same shape and 
size as the 
> Key.
> 
> "Excellent!  We're on the right track, my brothers!  The Divine One 
is 
> smiling upon us for sure!" the Archbishop yelled out in excitement 
as he 
> thrust the Key into the hole in the mountain, a bright emerald 
flash 
> momentarily blinding the Brotherhood.
> 
> When they could see again, there was a twenty foot high and ten 
foot wide 
> circular hole in the side of the volcano.  
> 
> "A tunnel." Reflector noted.  "Is this a Lore Shrine, Archbishop?"
> 
> "It can't be." Sun Crusher answered before Vehement could actually 
focus on 
> the question as he started to step into the tunnel.  "A Lore Shrine 
would not 
> be this hard to find and wouldn't be in the middle of a 
geographical 
> structure.  This...Rapa Kao--"
> 
> "Rana Kao." Vehement corrected.  "Do not say it wrong again.  
Follow me." he 
> said, pressing against the a side of the rocky tunnel, the tunnel 
> illuminating brightly with an unknown source of light.  The 
Brotherhood 
> leader walked down the tunnel swiftly, with a sense of eagerness to 
find out 
> more about the strange Rano Kao.
> 
> "Are you sure it's safe?" asked Sun Crusher, seeming to be 
afriad.  "We don't 
> know what the slag this thing is!  That Warrior of Primus was 
defeated rather 
> quickly and gave up the Key rather easily.  This may be a -- AIGH!" 
> 
> The Brotherhood second-in-command collapsed to the ground, grabbing 
his head 
> and twisting around violently in a fetal position.
> 
> Vehement's optics glowed a bright red, his right fist aloft.  "Do 
not 
> question me." the Archbishop said, letting his fest go into a flat 
hand, the 
> pain seeming to stop in Sun Crusher.  "The Warriors of Primus have 
always 
> been weak.  They've never been able to defeat the Brotherhood, even 
its 
> beginnings!  They were never able to defeat the Divine One, even 
when their 
> messiah was at his height of power!  We will continue on, and if 
any of you 
> speak cowardly words again, I shall kill you myself!"
> 
> He twirled on a foot, walking back down the path with his two 
minion slowly 
> in tow.  
> 
> The walk seemed to last an eternity to Vehement, but in the real 
world it 
> only had been less than a minute when they reached a wall of solid 
rock.
> 
> "A dead en--" Sun Crusher stopped in fear, but Vehement payed no 
heed.  
> Instead the Archbishop put a palm against the rock, and in an 
emerald flash 
> it was gone, but a wall of rock was in place behind them.
> 
> "Follow me." Vehement said.  They walked, feeling like an eternity, 
going 
> through different corners and more sealing and unsealing of rocky 
tunnels.  
> After the ternity that was really ten cycles they reached another 
dead end.
> 
> The Archbishop set a palm against the wall, but nothing happened.  
Suddenly 
> his look of confusion changed to one of certainty, and his red 
optics changed 
> to a green color with a bright hue around them.  
> 
> "THAT WHICH DOES NOT BECOME ONE WITH THE BROTHERHOOD, WILL BECOME 
ONE WITH 
> THE GREAT VOID" 
> 
> The voice had come from Vehement, but it wasn't his, and it seemed 
to be 
> disembodied, though it WAS coming from Vehement.  But the sheer 
will and 
> power of it was somewhat overwhelming.
> 
> The Archbishop shook his head, his optics back to their normal 
color.  He 
> stood for a second, almost jumping as a rather large rocky wall 
slid upward, 
> pebbles hitting the ground near him.  
> 
> ---
> 
> The Guardian's sensors detected the three Cybertronian followers of 
its 
> master, and had opened the entrance to the room after receiving the 
special 
> orders from its own master.  
> 
> Vehement and his two followers walked into the room, which suddenly 
> illuminated with another unknown source of light.  The room had to 
be at 
> least a hundred feet wide and fifty feet high.  Leaning down from 
the roof 
> like icicles were stalactites in an innumerable amount that were 
five feet 
> long at least.
> 
> On the floor all over there were stalagmites at at most three feet 
high.  
> Seeming to weave through the stalagmites were an almost 
innumberable amount 
> of computer terminals.  Of course the most interesting was the 
golden 
> Guardian in the very back of the cavern.  An several feet to the 
left of the 
> Guardian was a large coffin like device with numerous red and 
emerald chords 
> sticking into the Guardian itself.
> 
> "By the Chaos-Bringer!  The Guardian computer!  I thought it was 
but a myth!" 
> Vehement yelled as he broke into a run faster than one would think 
a sixteen 
> foot high robot could run.  He stopped at the fifteen foot high 
Guardian 
> computer shaped like a golden pyramid more beautiful than the 
Greaty Pyramids 
> of Egypt, even when there limestone hadn't been stolen by petty 
theives.
> 
> "I have waited for this day for two hundred years, not even a small 
fraction 
> of the time of our Lord's exitance.  I have read much abou this 
computer in 
> our scrolls.  Whatever you see, do not interfere, or I will kill 
you myself.  
> Disturb anything and I will kill you myself.  Our Lord spoke 
through us, and 
> has given me an insight, bless him."
> 
> With that, Vehement stepped right up to the Guardian, a 
concentrated golden 
> hue in the shape of a tendril slowly edged its way out of the 
Guardian (the 
> entire computer covered in a golden hue) and seemed to go through 
Vehement's 
> armor and into his very head.  A very dim golden glow surrounded 
the 
> Archbishop's entire head and most of his neck.
> 
> For an hour he remained like this, no sign that he was even alive.  
But just 
> as quickly as it had appeared, the tendril pulled out of Vehement 
and 
> disappeared back into the Guardian.
> 
> Sun Crusher and Reflector ran over to their leader, helping him 
stand in time 
> just as he was about to fall over onto his back.
> 
> "Energon...need...sustanance..." he said in a quiet voice, his 
optics rather 
> dim.
> 
> "Of course, Archbishop." Reflector said, pulling out a rectangular 
piece of 
> pink energon, slipping it into Vehement's mouth and the Archbishop 
devoured 
> it like he hadn't had any in his two hundred years of existance.
> 
> "Excellent, my brethren.  The Guardian computer merely took all my 
knowledge 
> and added it to its own.  While it accessed me, I was able to 
access it.  It 
> was adding to its knowledge and seeking updates of the situation of 
the 
> Universe and draining energy because it is lacking.
> 
> "I was able to learn what Rana Kao, even what Rapa Nui are.  A 
prison for our 
> Divine One, but he was able to take control of the Guardian.  Let 
us bring 
> him back immediately!" he yelled, walking over to the coffin shaped 
> equipment.  Placing a hand in an imprint in the machinery shaped 
like a 
> robot's hand, Vehement found his fit perfectly.  Not a surprise 
since he knew 
> what the Guardian knew.  Twisting his arm, the imprint twisted as 
well, the 
> top of the device blowing off, knocking Vehement onto his back, 
though 
> quickly sitting up to watch.
> 
> Out of the coffin shaped device a mighty roar erupted, and a burst 
of emerald 
> energy shot up, dispersing just as it was about to hit the ceiling 
and some 
> stalactites.
> 
> Out stepped a being sixteen feet in height, able to be clearly seen 
by anyone 
> in the volcano, espcecially the three Brotherhood members.
> 
> /I WALK ONCE MORE, MY FOLLOWERS.  I, UNICRON, YOUR DIVINE ONE, 
SHALL REWARD 
> YOU FOR YOUR YEARS OF SERVICE./
> 
> /ESPECIALLY YOU, VEHEMENT/ a disembodied voice roared throughout 
the great 
> cavern with so many technological wonders.  The voice itself seemed 
to be 
> ethereal and also seemed to demand much respect, awe, and fear.
> 
> Before the Brotherhood could speak, an bright green flash struck 
them all, 
> and they stood where they were, arms raised and screaming in pain 
as their 
> forms began to rip apart at the molecular level.
